titleStmt.title: A Guide to the United States’ History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Democratic Republic of the Congo
Democratic Republic of the Congo

sourceDesc.p: Researched and written by Christopher Morrison, February 2009

div.head: Summary
div.p: The United States recognized the Democratic Republic of the Congo’s independence in 1960 and established diplomatic relations at the same time.

figure.head: Modern Flag of The Democratic Republic of the Congo

div.head: U.S. Recognition of Congo’s Independence, 1960.
div.p: The United States recognized the Republic of Congo (Democratic Republic of the Congo) on June 30, 1960, in a congratulatory message from President Dwight D. Eisenhower to President Kasavubu. On that date, the area formerly known as the Belgian Congo was proclaimed independent from Belgian sovereignty.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations and the American Embassy, 1960.
div.p: Diplomatic relations were established on June 30, 1960, when the American Embassy in Leopoldville (now Kinshasha) was established with John D. Tomlinson as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim.
